Legal_Issue: Did the Citizenship Judge correctly apply the residency requirement under section 5(1) of the Citizenship Act?
Application_Facts: Applicant must accumulate 1095 days of residence in Canada within four years before applying for citizenship. The Citizenship Judge determined residency began on October 2, 2002, resulting in 922 days, which is 173 days short.
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application denied due to insufficient residency days
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of Citizenship Judge’s decision
Court_Ruling: Application for judicial review dismissed; Citizenship Judge's decision upheld
Defendant_Behavior: Citizenship Judge applied the residency requirement as per statutory interpretation
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged incorrect application of the residency requirement
Assessment_Factor: Physical presence in Canada; qualitative test not triggered due to lack of special hardships or exceptional services
Evidence_Used: Dates of physical presence in Canada
Evidence_Assessed: Record of days physically present in Canada
Relief_Sought: Overturn of Citizenship Judge’s decision and grant of citizenship
Governing_Rule: Applicant must have 1095 days of residence in Canada within four years prior to application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient documented days of residency (922 days instead of 1095)
Harm_Assessment: No harm found; decision deemed reasonable
Cause_Description: Li Zhang's citizenship application was denied due to insufficient residency days
Evidence_Handling: Residency dates were calculated based on available records
Evidence_Issues: No evidence of special circumstances to justify discretion despite shortfall
Evidence_Assessment: Days of physical presence assessed; no credit given for time before deemed residency start date
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge reasonably interpreted and applied the law; no reviewable error found
Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of documentation or proof to establish additional qualifying residency days
